body:
Unfortunately we're trapped in something of a mess here. pyo3 0.15 (which we currently use) doesn't support pypy 3.9 (see https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/pull/6887 for reasons). pyo3 0.16 does support pypy 3.9, however it drops support for python 3.6. Python 3.6 is currently 15% or so of our downloads, so we are not prepared to drop support for it.

What this means is that we do not currently have a way to support both pypy3.9 and python 3.6, and right now 3.6 is a much larger share of our users.
Well, Python 3.6 is EOL so no point in supporting it with future cryptography updates. You should move on as py03 guys did.

Regrettably, that's not how this works. Python 3.6 is still >15% of our downloads, because it still receives support in various linux distributions. While upstream EOL is one factor in when we drop something, first and foremost we're guided by trying to minimize our breakage budget: https://alexgaynor.net/2021/oct/07/whats-in-a-version-number/

New major release then maybe? And latest one with Python 3.6 compatibility receiving security updates for some time?
People will hit this incompatibility more often in near future so you will have to do something about it anyway.
Hello, is there any instruction for modify dependency of pyo3 in source code and manually build for the PyPy 7.3.8?

You can update the cargo dependency version in `Cargo.toml` and then run `cargo update -p pyo3` from within `src/rust`. This can be done in the release tarball or git branch. I don't know if there are any code changes on our end to work with the newer pyo3 though so be sure it compiles and passes the test suite.

`cryptography` has historically opposed security update only branches (not least because we don't have the time or energy to put into doing that well) and we're unlikely to do so for this scenario either. It is very unfortunate that we're in this situation, but if we're forced to choose between supporting Python 3.6 or PyPy 3.9 we'll be choosing 3.6 for now.

Yes, code changes are required to support pyo3 0.16

On Fri, Mar 4, 2022 at 8:29 PM Paul Kehrer ***@***.***> wrote:

> You can update the cargo dependency version in Cargo.toml and then run cargo
> update -p pyo3 from within src/rust. This can be done in the release
> tarball or git branch. I don't know if there are any code changes on our
> end to work with the newer pyo3 though so be sure it compiles and passes
> the test suite.
>
> cryptography has historically opposed security update only branches (not
> least because we don't have the time or energy to put into doing that well)
> and we're unlikely to do so for this scenario either. It is very
> unfortunate that we're in this situation, but if we're forced to choose
> between supporting Python 3.6 or PyPy 3.9 we'll be choosing 3.6 for now.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/6924#issuecomment-1059641897>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAAGBH5GVWDXOMCK2CVGY3U6K2JLANCNFSM5PXSBOHQ>
> .
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS
> <https://apps.apple.com/app/apple-store/id1477376905?ct=notification-email&mt=8&pt=524675>
> or Android
> <https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.github.android&referrer=utm_campaign%3Dnotification-email%26utm_medium%3Demail%26utm_source%3Dgithub>.
>
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>


-- 
All that is necessary for evil to succeed is for good people to do nothing.

> While upstream EOL is one factor in when we drop something, first and foremost we're guided by trying to minimize our breakage budget: https://alexgaynor.net/2021/oct/07/whats-in-a-version-number/

I (re-)read that article, and yet I don't see how this enters into the breakage budget. People on py36 would simply stop receiving updates (yet keep a working cryptography installation), rather than being "broken".

@h-vetinari Unfortunately ~90% of our users get `cryptography` from a wheel and by necessity we statically link OpenSSL within that wheel. This means that when we drop support nearly everyone no longer receives security updates of any kind, including for the underlying critical cryptographic dependency. My own concern is specifically that I am unwilling to silently leave 15% of users out in the cold. We are a core dependency for a huge part of the Python ecosystem and while we are quite aggressive in driving upgrades where we can, telling 15% of our user base that they need to upgrade to 3.7+ in this case is simply too much "breakage" for people who depend on us.

It's certainly a laudable approach. I don't particularly agree with the assumption that it falls on you to bridge the (security) gap for someone running on EOL software yet expecting up-to-date security (especially large corporate IT), but that's your call to make.
I assume that if PyO3 released a `0.15.x` with pypy-3.9 support backported and python-3.6 support still in place, the cryptography project would update to that version, right?

Yes, we would.

On Tue, Mar 29, 2022 at 4:43 PM Jan Segre ***@***.***> wrote:

> I assume that if PyO3 released a 0.15.1 with pypy-3.9 support backported
> and python-3.6 support still in place, the cryptography project would
> update to that version, right?
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/6924#issuecomment-1082355632>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAAGBEB2ZPHLUUPHZQULBLVCNTQLANCNFSM5PXSBOHQ>

> ***@***.***>

All that is necessary for evil to succeed is for good people to do nothing.

issue.title: Version 0.15.2 with support for Pypy 3.9 and Python 3.6

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: pyo3
repository.description: Rust bindings for the Python interpreter

issue.body:
Hi! First of all, thanks for building and maintaining this project!

The cryptography project, which depends on this PyO3, is currently unable to provide support for Pypy with Python 3.9, because a large portion of their users still use Python 3.6, which was dropped in version 0.16 of PyO3, the same that first includes support for Pypy 3.9.

This is the relevant issue: https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/6924

It has been suggested that a new patch release could be used to solve this issue, for example a version 0.15.2 adding support for Pypy 3.9 while also keeping support for Python 3.6.

Is that feasible? Would a pull request be accepted? If yes, can you give me some pointers or tips so that I can start working on this?

body: I created an issue on PyO3 asking if that's doable: https://github.com/PyO3/pyo3/issues/2260 (note that I said version 0.15.2 there, because version 0.15.1 already exists).

issue.title: Rebuild for PyPy3.8 and PyPy3.9
